Pit_Observation.pitNotes: In the afternoon, we stopped again to look at the bottom of Path #18B to assess our uncertainty regarding spatial variability and to confirm test results from the pit earlier in the morning. We also looked at snow temperatures this time to consider diurnal recrystallization during a warm part of the day.

User.name: Banff Visitor Safety

Location.range: Banff, Yoho and Kootenay National Parks
Location.name: Sunshine Study Plot

Pit_Observation.pitNotes: N thru W aspects on the north slope of the Uintas have been stripped more than usual from the strong December wind events. HS is generally only around one meter because of this. 4F facets near the ground are still dry and not changing much. Its been so long since the last real storm, this layer is dormant for now. New variable rime crust at the surface from 1/21. Will it persist??

Snow is stabilizing well lower layer facets from October are healing and locking together. The column during the ECT test never failed. The only concern will be future loading on the top layer of snow that is beginning to crystallize and become loose and will likely be a weak point once loaded.

Pit_Observation.activities: We skied slope;
Pit_Observation.pitNotes: We were curious how the facets near the ground are holding up in this region.
Gentle lee NE roll near ridgetop. Only able to isolate ECT 28cm down due to crust

Pit_Observation.pitNotes: On our morning evaluation of the pass, we dug a quick pit to look at the upper layers of the snowpack around the sun crust.
Pit dug adjacent to a ski area. Did not dig to ground. Significant rime deposits from wind blown rime off trees.
Observers: BJ, CD Note: ECTX but ECTP on 2 extra-hard taps down 31 cm on 0.5 mm faceted rounds.

Pit_Observation.activities: We skied slope;
Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Very light powder snowfall (30 cm), but at the beginning with some wind, which consolidated slightly a lower powder layer; In the following days strong NE winds, they blew off the powder at the higher parts of the slops and crated lots of wind-loads on S slopes! Concerns about growing facets below a thin crust layer (at some other locations a bit thicker, but still not so solid)!
ALP. Lätt marknära drev. Vindutsatt plats innan det blir riktigt brant. TORRT snötäcke= inget regn på nivån den 18/1.

Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Another quick pit dug at the bottom of Path 18B on Sylvan Pass to look at how the new Jan 20 storm snow may interact with the sun curst and faceting below that crust.
Xh triggered wind slab which stepped down to Dec FC and Nov 5th. Confirmed avalanche size 3.5, reached the burm.

Pit_Observation.activities: Pit dug in a Ski Area;
Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Pit Dug in an area treated with Avalanche Mitigation on 1/13 Significant vegetation at ground
A quick snow profile was dug on Sylvan Pass at the very bottom of Path #8 just off the road.

DH at ground healing. Weakest layer is by far the combination of faceted layers near the surface. If the top layer of surf hoar is destroyed, there are several layers of fc's below it that should survive and cause problems.

Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Pit dug in bed surface of avalanche that occurred near Jan 5. Old faceted snow still exists near the ground but is 1F-4F minus in hardness. Weakest snow is at surface and 20cm below surface at 1mm NSF.

Pit_Observation.activities: Pit dug in a Ski Area; We skied slope;

Pit_Observation.pitNotes: We only did a CT because the facets were buried so deep. 200-225cm seems accurate for depth at this elevation.

Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Ylempänä M/S etelätuulta. Maa kivirakkaa. Epävakaata. Jyrkemmälle ei olisi uskaltanut kävellä.
Upper Desperado, under first cliff band. Snow surface stripped, shale ground cover.

This pit location is a known shallower spot just above the treeline on an alpine slope. The overlying slab in this area is connected to a part of the slope where the slab is thicker. Still observing hard failures in tests where the overlying slab is thin.

Weakest interface was a very thin layer of facets sandwiched between recent wind slab and firm midpack roughly a foot below the snow surface. Slides triggered in this layer could step down to the ground (basal facets).

Ski tracks on slope; We skied slope; Snowmobile tracks on slope;
Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Days prior have been calm and warm compared to cold past week. -20 temps at night. Christmas week delivered the goods for the entire San Juans with 1-3 meters of new snow drifting in from strong SW winds over 100mph+. Basal facets are found NE-NW ATL-BTL and likely to be reactive throughout the season.
